newsitem.title: USA: Coffee prices soar as U.S. stocks evaporate.
newsitem.headline: Coffee prices soar as U.S. stocks evaporate.

text.p: Coffee prices rose Monday amid growing concern about tight supplies worldwide.
"There just is not any real amount of coffee around," said analyst Judith Ganes of Merrill Lynch. "And there probably won't be for a few weeks.
Trade and speculative buying drove the December contract sharply higher as the market awaited weekly data on U.S. certified stocks, which was issued after the close.

The report showed a drop of 4,036 132-pound bags to just 1,547 bags and prompted New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange (CSCE) to seek more money from traders wishing to trade in the volatile December contract.
December coffee rose 3.10 cents to 119.10 cents a pound at the CSCE.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 0.07 points to 243.33, bolstered partly by the rise in coffee.
Wheat prices fell again as the United States struggled to compete on the export market with rivals such as Argentina.

"Wheat continues to react to the fact it is overvalued compared to world values," said Mark Cermak of Chicago trade house O'Connor and Co. "Argentina is selling wheat and that has the Europeans putting on subsidies."

Memphis-based analytical firm Sparks Cos. also raised its estimate for Argentine wheat production for next year to 15.1 million metric tons from a previous projection of 14.25 million, further depressing the market's mood.
December wheat fell 7-1/2 cents to $3.82-1/4 a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade, after hitting a peak of $7.50 a bushel earlier this year.
Gasoline prices ended higher in New York but crude oil and heating oil fell.

Gasoline for November delivery ended up 0.20 cent at 70.30 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange after prices rose to a six-month high of 71.75 cents a gallon. November heating oil ended off 0.26 cent at 71.46 cents a gallon.
December crude oil fell one cent to $24.85 a barrel.

"People were looking for a reason to sell heating oil and buy gasoline, and the refinery problems were a convenient excuse," said Michael Rothman, senior energy futures analyst at Merrill Lynch, of gasoline's sharp intraday rise.

Environmental regulators said a valve failure caused an operation upset of gasoline making unit at Amoco Corp.'s 433,000 barrel a day Texas City, Texas, refinery. An Amoco spokeswoman declined to comment on the incident, except to say, "This is part of day-to-day operations."
"The problem with the Amoco refinery is probably not that bad," said Rita Beale, an analyst with Fimat USA Futures.
Meanwhile, Lagoven, an affiliate of Petroleos de Venezuela, said that part of its Amuay refinery in Venezuala would be back online in three weeks after being shut due to problems with its compressor.
The Lagoven news combined with views that Amoco's refinery problems were minimal depressed prices, traders said.
Lagoven also reiterated that it would be able to meet supply contracts despite the shutdown.
"The market turned south on a combination of refinery news," said a trader.
